DOCNAME: CASE OF MAMMADLI AND OTHERS v. AZERBAIJAN
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 3 of Protocol No. 1 - Right to free elections-{general} (Article 3 of Protocol No. 1 - Stand for election);Violation of Article 34 - Individual applications (Article 34 - Hinder the exercise of the right of petition)
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicants’ dates of birth and places of residence are given in the Appendix .
CARDINAL . Tahirov v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE ) and PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL , DATE ) .

CARDINAL . The applicants stood as candidates in the parliamentary elections of CARDINAL DATE and applied for registration as candidates in various single – mandate electoral constituencies ( see Appendix ) .

CARDINAL . The respective ORG ( “ ConECs ” ) on various dates ( see Appendix ) refused the ORG requests for registration as a candidate after the PERSON working groups had found that some of the supporting voter signatures submitted by the applicants were invalid and that the remaining valid signatures had numbered CARDINAL , a minimum required by law . Signatures were found to be invalid on several grounds in each case .

CARDINAL . None of the applicants , except the applicant in application no . CARDINAL , were invited to the ConEC meetings where decisions to refuse their requests for registration were taken . In each case , despite the requirements of the law , all the relevant working group documents and the ConEC decision itself were made available to the applicants belatedly or never made available to them .

CARDINAL . Each applicant lodged a complaint with ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) against the ConEC decisions . The points raised in their complaints were similar to those made by the applicants in GPE ( cited above , § § CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) and LOC ( cited above , § § PERCENT ) .

CARDINAL . On various dates , the ORG also rejected the ORG complaints ( see Appendix ) , after another examination of the signature sheets by members of its own working group , which had found in each case that large numbers of signatures were invalid and that the remaining valid signatures were below the minimum required by law .

CARDINAL . None of the applicants were invited to attend the relevant ORG or working group meetings . Moreover , in each case , all the relevant ORG documents were only made available to the applicants after the ORG decision had been taken .

CARDINAL . NORP On various dates , each of the applicants lodged an appeal with ORG against the decisions of the electoral commissions . They reiterated the complaints they had made before the ORG concerning the ConEC decisions and procedures . They also raised a number of other points similar to those raised by the applicants in GPE ( cited above , § CARDINAL ) and LOC ( cited above , § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . On various dates ( see Appendix ) , ORG dismissed appeals by the applicants , finding that their arguments were irrelevant or unsubstantiated and that there were no grounds for quashing the decisions of the ORG .

CARDINAL . The applicants lodged cassation appeals with ORG , reiterating their previous complaints and arguing that ORG had not carried out a fair examination of the cases and had delivered unreasoned judgments .

CARDINAL . On various dates ( see Appendix ) , ORG dismissed the ORG appeals as unsubstantiated , without examining their arguments in detail , and found no grounds to doubt the findings of the electoral commissions or of ORG .

CARDINAL . In addition to the applicants in the present cases , at the material time Mr PERSON , the applicants’ representative in applications nos . CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL and DATE , was representing a total of twentyseven applicants in cases concerning the DATE parliamentary elections and a number of applicants in other cases before the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE criminal proceedings were instituted against Mr I. GPE , which are the subject of a separate application brought by him before the ORG ( application no . CARDINAL ) . On CARDINAL and CARDINAL DATE the investigation authorities seized a large number of documents from Mr I. GPE ’s office including all the case files relating to the pending proceedings before ORG , which were in Mr PERSON ’s possession and which concerned over CARDINAL applications in total . The files relating to applications nos . CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL and CARDINAL were also seized in their entirety . The facts relating to the seizure and the relevant proceedings are described in more detail in LOC ( cited above , § § DATE ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigation authorities returned a number of the case files concerning the applications lodged before the ORG , including the file relating to applications nos . CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL andCARDINAL/CARDINAL , to Mr PERSON ’s lawyer .
